qas.question: In Germany, Poland and Austria Romanesque architecture is defined by its massive size and what other design element?
What design style does Romanesque architecture in Germany, Poland, and Austria normally follow?
What does the eastern end of German Romanesque cathedrals typically emulate?
What is the distinguishing design element in German Gothic cathedrals?
What are hall churches in German cathedrals known as?
What design style does Romanesque architecture in Germany, Poland, and Australia rarely follow?
What does the eastern end of German Romanesque cathedrals typically avoid?
What is the only design element in German Gothic cathedrals?
What are hall churches in German cathedrals no longer known as?

context: Romanesque architecture in Germany, Poland, the Czech Lands and Austria is characterised by its massive and <a0_0>modular nature<a0_0/>. This is expressed in the Gothic architecture of Central Europe in the huge size of the towers and spires, often projected, but not always completed. The west front generally follows <a1_0><b5_0>the French formula<b5_0/><a1_0/>, but the towers are very much taller and, if complete, are surmounted by enormous openwork spires that are a regional feature. Because of the size of the towers, the section of the façade between them may appear narrow and compressed. The eastern end <a2_0>follows <b6_0>the French form<b6_0/><a2_0/>. The distinctive character of the interior of German Gothic cathedrals is <a3_0><b7_0>their breadth and openness<b7_0/><a3_0/>. This is the case even when, as at Cologne, they have been modelled upon a French cathedral. German cathedrals, like the French, tend not to have strongly projecting transepts. There are also many hall churches (<a4_0><b8_0>Hallenkirchen<b8_0/><a4_0/>) without clerestory windows.
